Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Alan Michael Twomey of the University of Minnesota to conduct a research project, entitled "Quantifying small-scale distribution of proteins in frozen solutions using chemical imaging techniques," during the summer of 2012 at Kyushu University in Fukuoka, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan. The host scientists are Dr. Hiroshi Takamastu and Dr. Kosaku Kurata

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to quantify the effect of cooling rate and thermal history on the distribution of proteins in the ice interface in solutions composed of cryoprotective agents and buffers. Using confocal Raman spectroscopy scans of solutions frozen along a temperature gradient, the distribution of the proteins are being measured, as well as changes in their conformation. The specific goal of the research project is to develop a methodology to control the interactions of a protein in a solution with a propagating ice interface in a manner that minimizes damage to the protein structure. Minimizing structural damage to proteins has significant implications for many applications, including the pharmaceutical industry where therapeutic proteins are frequently stabilized and stored at length in the frozen state.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freezing and freeze-drying are common techniques used to stabilize macromolecules (e.g. proteins and enzymes) for long-term storage in the pharmaceutical industry. During freezing in water-based solutions, complex interactions occur between the growing ice phase and the remaining liquid solution, which becomes increasingly concentrated as the solutes (proteins, buffers, and chemicals called cryoprotectants that are meant to protect the proteins during freezing) are rejected from the ice phase.

The research this summer at Kyushu University focused on the freezing of model macromolecule and cryoprotectant solutions under both equilibrium (slow) and non-equilibrium (fast) freezing conditions. Existing data in the literature suggest that protein accumulates at the ice interface during freezing. This is of interest, because interactions with ice during freezing can cause structural damage to proteins, diminishing product yield and efficacy in the pharmaceutical industry.

The initial aim was to study interactions between proteins and ice during slow freezing using the chemical imaging technique confocal Raman microscopy (CRM). The subsequent aim was to identify non-equilibrium freezing conditions that would minimize harmful protein-ice interactions. This was done by freezing solutions along a temperature gradient, encompassing a range of freezing conditions, and then mapping the distribution of solutes along the temperature gradient.

To evaluate protein and ice interactions, solutions of a cryoprotectant, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and a common protein, bovine serum albumin, were frozen and then warmed until a small amount of ice remained at a given temperature. The liquid phase surrounding the ice phase was then scanned using CRM. In subsequent experiments, the solutions were increasingly diluted. To freeze the diluted solutions under near-equilibrium conditions, the solutions were frozen, warmed slowly until little ice remained, then cooled slowly to a given temperature. With complete rejection of the solutes from the ice phase and no other interactions, the remaining liquid phase of all the solutions at that same temperature would be identical and there simply would be more ice present in the more dilute solutions.

Calibration experiments were performed using solutions with a fixed concentration of DMSO and varying amounts of protein in order to quantify concentration. The results of these experiments are being submitted for publication, and as a result, are not reported here.

Non-equilibrium (fast) freezing experiments were performed using solutions of bovine serum albumin and trehalose, which is a sugar used as a cryoprotectant. A microchannel of the solution was placed between a warm (16°C) and a cool (-20°C) stage, separated by a small gap. Ice was nucleated at the cold end, after which CRM was used to scan along the frozen channel. Using these CRM scans, the distribution of the protein and cryoprotectant were mapped and determined as a function of cooling conditions. Detailed results of these experiments are being submitted for publication, and so are not reported here.
